sources.title: The Old Dark House (1932) | Colorized Public Domain Horror Mystery Classic Directed by James Whale
sources.description:
The Old Dark House (1932) is a pre-Code American horror film directed by James Whale, best known for his work on Frankenstein (1931) and The Invisible Man (1933). Originally produced and distributed by Universal Pictures, this atmospheric classic blends gothic horror, suspense, and dark comedy. Presented here in a restored and colorized edition, it revives one of the greatest haunted-house thrillers of early Hollywood for modern audiences in the United States, Europe, and beyond.

Plot Summary:
A group of weary travelers seek shelter from a violent storm in a remote Welsh mansion owned by the mysterious and eccentric Femm family. Inside, they encounter bizarre and unsettling hosts: Horace Femm, a nervous recluse; his religiously fanatical sister Rebecca; the mute and scarred butler Morgan; and the sinister presence of a locked-away family member whose danger grows as the night unfolds. As the storm rages, secrets, madness, and murder emerge from the shadows of the house.

The film stands out for its chilling atmosphere, razor-sharp dialogue, and a mix of horror and satire that keeps audiences both uneasy and amused. Its gothic setting and strange characters established a blueprint for countless haunted-house films that followed.

metadata.Plot: Seeking shelter from a pounding rainstorm in a remote region of Wales, several travellers are admitted to a gloomy, foreboding mansion belonging to the extremely strange Femm family. Trying to make the best of it, the guests must deal with their sepulchral host, Horace Femm and his obsessive, malevolent sister Rebecca. Things get worse as the brutish manservant Morgan gets drunk, runs amuck and releases the long pent-up brother Saul, a psychotic pyromaniac who gleefully tries to destroy the residence by setting it on fire.
